SELECTED PROJECTS

Web App Rhetorical Framing Explorator — Earlier NLP studies on framing in journalistic texts tend to oversimplify framing as a mere matter of topic coverage. However, framing is not about what is said, but how things are said. For instance, as readers we sense that these two sentences convey very different attitudes: "The ruling parties do not understand what family means for the refugees" vs. "The ruling parties do not even understand what family means for the refugees".

However, such nuanced language usage is heavily understudied in NLP. This is partially due to the reason that NLP studies increasingly use black-box models (e.g., LLMs) that do not allow a drilling down into the effects of linguistically meaningful components. I am developing a web App which facilitates the exploration of such subtle linguistic aspects of framing.

Relevant Resources: (under develop) ; see an older version without UI in Yu (2023)
Examining Behaviors of Large Language Models — LLMs are powerful, but model explainability is also crucial for many use cases - what have they actually learned from the training data and why do they come to a certain decision? For text data, this is especially relevant for complex tasks such as the automated detection of non-literal meaning, e.g., sarcasm or metaphor.

My colleagues and I probe the performance of diverse black-box LLMs and compare them with white-box (explainable) models on the task of figurative language classification. Fun fact: for this probing task, we found that black-box models are not that unexplainable, whereas white-box models are sometimes not really human-interpretable.

Relevant Resources: Yu (2023)
Large-Scale Experimental Studies on Coinage Compounds — This project is more of a cognitive science (psycholinguistics) nature. The German language is rich of compounds, and new compounds can always be derivated - you might know crazy examples like "Donaudampfschiffahrtsgesellschaftskapitän". In journalism, sometimes authors employ innovate compounds to implicitly convey biased attitudes.

For instance, what impact on readers' perceptions does it make to call an intern who wears a hijab because of her religious background as "the hijab-intern" (original in German: Kopftuchpraktikantin) instead of "the intern who wears a hijab" (German: kopftuchtragende Praktikantin)? In collaboration with the University of Tübingen, I designed experiments to unravel this.

Relevant Resources: Yu et al. (2024, accepted)
